contextId.information: Often such thoughts could come unintentionally, without the person wanting to think them. AT: "cursed God in their thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: cursed God in their hearts

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to God's power to act. "But now use your power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: But now stretch out your hand

contextId.information: Here "touch" represents the action of harming or destroying. AT: "attack all that he has" or "destroy all that he has" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: touch all that he has

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents someone's power to control something. AT: "you have power over all that he has." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all that he has is in your hand

contextId.information: Here striking represents killing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: have struck

contextId.information: "Skin" is a metonym for Job's life. AT: "A person will do anything to save his own life, even accept the loss of possessions and loved ones." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Skin for skin, indeed

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to God's power to act. "But now use your power." Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:09|01:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: stretch out your hand

contextId.information: This expression represents Job's body. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: his bones and his flesh

contextId.information: Here Job's adversary's "hand" is a metonym for his adversary's power. Job uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that he did not ask them to save him. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "I never asked any of you to rescue me from my enemies" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Save me from my adversary's hand?

contextId.information: God's "eyes" represent his seeing or noticing Job. AT: "God who watches me ... God will look for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The eye of God, who sees me ... God's eyes will be on me

contextId.information: Here the heart represents the inner being or thoughts. AT: "wise in what he decides" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: wise in heart

contextId.information: Here "mouth" represents Job's words. AT: "my own words would accuse me" or "what I say would condemn me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my own mouth would condemn me

contextId.information: Here "God's rod" is a metonym for God punishing or correcting Job. AT: "stop God from punishing me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: take God's rod off me

contextId.information: Job's troubles from God are spoken of as if they were people who were witnesses against him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: You bring new witnesses against me

contextId.information: The hand represents what a person does. AT: "even if you had done some evil things in the past" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: suppose that iniquity were in your hand

contextId.information: "Lifting up your face" represents the attitude of a person who is confident and brave. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: lift up your face without a sign of shame

contextId.information: 'Their own hands" is a metonym for strength, and "their gods" is a  metaphor for their pride. AT: "they are extremely proud of their own abilities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their own hands are their gods

contextId.information: Possible meanings are that 1) this is a metonym for making kings no longer have authority. AT: He takes away the authority of kings" or 2) this is a metonym for setting people free from the chains that kings have put on them. AT: "he takes off the bonds that kings have put on people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He takes off the chain of authority from kings

contextId.information: Removing their speech represents making them unable to speak. AT: "He makes those who were trusted unable to speak" or "He silences people whom others trusted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He removes the speech of those who had been trusted

contextId.information: Footsteps represent his life or what he does  AT: "my life" or "the things I do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my footsteps

contextId.information: This refers to the Job and Eliphaz by their "mouths" to place emphasis what they say. AT: "You are condemned by what you say, not by what I say" or "You condemn yourself by what you say, it is not I who condemn you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Your own mouth condemns you, not mine

contextId.information: Here the "heart" represents a person's emotions. AT: "Why do your emotions take you away?" or "Why do you allow your emotions to guide your decisions?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Why does your heart carry you away?

contextId.information: Darkness here represents death. AT: "out of the darkness of death" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: out of darkness

contextId.information: Job speaks of his vision as his "eyes." AT: "My vision has become weak because I am so sad" or "I am almost blind because of my sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My eye is also dim because of sorrow

contextId.information: The word "light" refers life, and the word "darkness" refers to death. AT: "from the light of life to the darkness of death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from light into darkness

contextId.information: Here "breath" represents the smell of his breath. If something is offensive to someone, it means that he hates it. AT: "My wife hates the smell of my breath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My breath is offensive to my wife

contextId.information: Possible meanings are that the sword represents 1) God judging them. AT: "then be afraid that God will judge you" or 2) God killing them. AT: "then be afraid that God will kill you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: then be afraid of the sword

contextId.information: Here "fill his stomach" is a metonym meaning eat a lot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to fill his stomach

contextId.information: The iron weapon represents the person carrying it. AT: "will flee from the person carrying an iron weapon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: will flee from the iron weapon

contextId.information: Possible meanings are: 1) those who live in the heavens and the earth (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]), or 2) Zophar is describing the heavens and the earth as if they are humans who will testify in court against the wicked person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The heavens ... the earth

contextId.information: Here "hands" refers to their power or control. Job uses this question to challenge his friends. AT: "Look, these wicked people claim that they make themselves prosper!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: See, is not their prosperity in their own hands?

contextId.information: Here "from his mouth" represents what God has spoken. AT: "the instruction that God has spoken" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: instruction from his mouth

contextId.information: Here "sets and end to darkness" represents shining a light in the darkness. People would use a flame, either in a lantern or on a torch. AT: "A man carries light into dark places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: A man sets an end to darkness

contextId.information: Here "bread" is a metonym for food in general. Food coming out of the ground is a metaphor for food growing in the ground. AT: "the earth, where food grows," (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the earth, out of which comes bread

contextId.information: This represents breaking up the rock. AT: "digs into the flinty rock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: lays his hand on the flinty rock

contextId.information: Here "sat" represents ruling or leading. Chiefs sat down when they made important decisions. AT: "led them as their chief" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sat as their chief

contextId.information: "the rabble rise upon my right hand." Possible meanings are 1) rising upon Job's right hand represents attacking his strength. AT: "Gangs of young people attack my strength" or 2) rising upon Job's right hand represents attacking his honor. AT: "Mobs attack my honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Upon my right hand rise the rabble

contextId.information: Job speaks of God using his force as if God's force were actually doing something.  AT: "God has seized my clothing by his great force" or It is as (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: God's great force has seized my clothing

contextId.information: The tent represents Job's household. The men of his tent includes family members and servants. All of these knew Job well. AT: "the men of my household" or "my family members and servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the men of my tent

contextId.information: Job is explaining how he truly treated foreigners. Here "stay in the city square" represents sleeping overnight in the city square.  AT: "foreigners have never had to sleep in the city square" or "foreigners have never had to sleep outside" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: even the foreigner has never had to stay in the city square

contextId.information: Here "hands" refer to power. AT: "for God made them all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for they all are the work of his hands

contextId.information: God's "eyes" represent his sight. The phrase "a person's ways" is an idiom for what he does and how he lives. AT: "For God watches everything a person does" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: For God's eyes are upon a person's ways

contextId.information: Here to "see" means to know. AT: "teach me what I have done wrong that I am not aware of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: teach me what I cannot see

contextId.information: Here the word "heart" refers to the thoughts and emotions. The phrase may indicate that the person stubbornly refuses to trust God. AT: "who refuse to trust in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who are godless in heart

contextId.information: The person is a metonym for the prayer he prays. AT: "God accepted Job's prayer for his three friends" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh accepted Job
